In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the solution in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump = 3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

# Testing the function
t = DateTime("2021-07-08T15:00:00")
println(timezone_bumper(t)) # This will print "2021-07-08T18:00:00"
```

This function accepts a DateTime type and an optional Int argument. If no second argument is provided, it defaults to 3 hours. The function simply adds the `bump` number of hours to the input datetime object.

If you try to pass a Date type to this function, Julia will throw an error:

```julia
t = Date("2021-07-08")
println(timezone_bumper(t)) # This will throw an error
```

This is because the `timezone_bumber` function only accepts DateTime types. If you try to pass a Date type, Julia will check the method table for a matching method and will not find one, hence it throws an error.
